doc.field: Sub-sub-series 5.3.2: Travel Log/Diary Entries, Correspondence and Drafts
Sub-sub-series 5.3.2: Travel Log/Diary Entries, Correspondence and Drafts

The sub-series consists mainly of handwritten drafts and typescripts of correspondence. This includes drafts of letters written by Alice Van Vliet and letters she received while she studied Classical Moderations at Oxford University, England, and traveled throughout Europe during the post-WWI period, 1924-1927. They conclude with correspondence from her time as a teacher at the Katherine Branson School in Ross, California. The tone of these letters is chatty and conversational, revealing personal experiences and the thrill of traveling and studying Classical Moderations at Oxford â€”referred to as "Mods" in many of her letters and diaries. The material in this Series is in good condition; most are not brittle, though some are difficult to read. Several of the letters were composed while on trains or boats and later typed. Because many of these letters are drafts, the paper is sometimes thin, the handwriting informal, and Van Vliet would often write on both sides of the paper in ink, which would seep through to the other side, thus making the letters almost entirely illegible.
